abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Urban Project for Ghana had
            the following ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, and the Bank and borrower performance
            were both satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that
            many development tasks require more years to accomplish than
            the life of a typical investment project, and phased
            instruments are very effective to build relevant
            institutions, deal with initial capacity constrains, and
            cope with changing interests and priorities of borrowing
            countries. Linking investment funds to performance
            incentives to improve local government capacity through
            learning by doing stimulates competition and increases the
            chances of achieving long-term development effectiveness.
            Professionals with backgrounds in financial management and
            institutional development should be put in leadership
            positions at the national level in projects that promote the
            decentralization of government service provision and the
            development of local government capacity. There was
            insufficient performance monitoring and evaluation of
            Ghana's construction industry within government.
            Sub-projects should be chosen with the participation of the
            affected population and should be prioritized by the DAs in
            Medium Term Development Plans. Projects assisted by several
            donors should be coordinated at the District level.
